meanings.definition: To bite or chew with the teeth.
meanings.sent1: The puppy tried to knawe on the bone.
meanings.sent2: She watched the rabbit knawe on a carrot.
meanings.sent3: The toddler loves to knawe on his teething toy.
meanings.sent4: Time seemed to knawe away at the old wooden fence.
meanings.sent5: The termite continued to knawe through the wood.

meanings.definition: To wear away or diminish by constant friction.
meanings.sent1: The river knawed at the rocks, smoothing them over time.
meanings.sent2: The constant rubbing of the rope began to knawe at the metal.
meanings.sent3: The wind and rain seemed to knawe at the ancient statue.
meanings.sent4: The sandpaper slowly knawed away the rough edges of the wood.
meanings.sent5: The waves knawed at the shore, reshaping it constantly.

meanings.definition: A person who is annoying or troublesome.
meanings.sent1: The knawe in class always disrupted the lesson.
meanings.sent2: She found it hard to deal with the knawe in the office.
meanings.sent3: The little brother was being a knawe, hiding her toys.
meanings.sent4: The knawe at the party kept telling bad jokes.
meanings.sent5: The neighborhood knawe was always causing trouble.
